title: 103_hr1317
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Franchise Data and Public Information Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings and purpose section. The Congress finds that franchise business relationships are a significant part of the American economy, but there is a lack of reliable data on the number and operation of franchise businesses. Statistical information on franchise businesses is scarce, with a lack of reliable data on ownership and operation. Misleading statistics are often found in promotional material, falsely portraying franchises as risk-free and uniformly successful. Franchise opportunities are often misrepresented as risk-free and uniformly successful, with inaccurate statistical information attributed to Federal Government agencies. Franchisees may face substantial losses due to misleading data on business operations and success. Franchisees may suffer losses from inaccurate or misleading statistical information about franchise businesses. The Act aims to provide comprehensive data on franchising to enhance public information and help investors make informed decisions. The Act aims to provide comprehensive data on franchising to enhance public information and help investors make informed decisions. SEC. 3. NATIONAL FILING AND DATA COLLECTION. The Act requires all entities selling franchises to file a copy of the franchise disclosure document with the Commerce Department. The document must be the most recent version. The franchise disclosure document must be filed with the Commerce Department and should be the most recent version that includes current information as of the franchisor's latest fiscal year. It should also be the most restrictive version provided to prospective franchisees in terms of requirements. The franchise disclosure document must be filed annually with the Commerce Department in the most restrictive version provided to prospective franchisees, outlining requirements and limitations in the franchise agreement. The Commerce Department requires the annual filing of the franchise disclosure document, with procedures for public viewing. It is prohibited for franchisors to make false statements in connection with advertisements or disclosure documents. It is illegal for franchisors to falsely claim that a disclosure document has been filed with the Commerce Department or imply that it has been reviewed by any federal agency. The Commerce Department prohibits franchisors from falsely claiming or implying that a disclosure document has been reviewed by any federal agency. The Department will establish procedures for data collection and publication within 240 days of this section's enactment. The Commerce Department will establish procedures for compiling statistical information on franchise ownership and national franchising practices within 240 days of the enactment of this section. The principal source of statistical information will be the disclosure documents for franchise opportunities required to be filed annually. The Commerce Department will use disclosure documents for franchise opportunities as the main source of statistical information on franchise ownership and practices. Categories of statistical information will be established for annual data compilation and analysis, including total numbers of franchisors and franchise businesses, types of franchise businesses, annual growth, and turnover. The Commerce Department will consult with various organizations to identify additional categories of statistical information for data compilation and analysis related to franchisors and franchise businesses. The Commerce Department will collaborate with organizations to identify more categories of statistical information for data analysis related to franchisors and franchise businesses, focusing on issues of public interest and regulatory concern. This information can be obtained from disclosure materials and other public sources. The Commerce Department collaborates with organizations to identify statistical information for analysis related to franchisors and franchise businesses. This information can be obtained from disclosure materials and public sources. Periodic questionnaires are initiated to supplement information in disclosure documents. The Commerce Department collaborates with organizations to identify statistical information for analysis related to franchisors and franchise businesses. Periodic questionnaires are used to supplement information in disclosure documents. No questionnaire information can replace data available in disclosure documents or the Business Census. The Commerce Department will publish a report on franchise ownership and national franchising practices, required under this subsection, within eighteen months of enactment and annually thereafter. The report will be sent to Congress Committees. The Commerce Department will publish a report on franchise ownership and national franchising practices as required by this subsection. The report will be transmitted to Congress Committees and made available to the public through the Superintendent of Documents. SEC. 4. Census data on franchise businesses. The Bureau of the Census will include statistical information on franchise businesses in its Business Census, consulting with the Federal Trade Commission and other organizations to establish criteria and collect relevant data. The Bureau of Census will include statistical information on franchise businesses in the Business Census, consulting with the Federal Trade Commission and other organizations to establish criteria for data collection. A report on cost-effective and accurate data gathering methods will be submitted to Congress within 280 days of this section's enactment. The Bureau of Census will submit a report to Congress detailing cost-effective and accurate methods for gathering statistical information on franchise businesses for inclusion in the Business Census. SEC. 5. RULES, REGULATIONS AND FEES. The Secretary of Commerce is authorized to make rules and regulations to implement the Act, including classifications, adjustments, and exceptions deemed necessary. Additionally, the Secretary can collect a filing fee. The Secretary of Commerce can make rules and regulations, including exceptions, to implement the Act and prevent evasion. They are also authorized to collect a filing fee from those subject to the filing requirement. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines "advertisement" as a communication circulated to the public in connection with a franchise sale, and "disclosure document" as a statement required by the Commission or an offering circular prepared according to guidelines. The term "franchise" refers to a commercial relationship where a franchisor grants a franchisee the right to sell goods or services. This is outlined in an offering circular prepared in accordance with franchise guidelines. The franchisor grants the franchisee the right to sell goods or services associated with the franchisor's trademark or commercial symbol. The franchisee must conform to quality standards established by the franchisor for the goods or services to be offered, sold, or distributed, and operate under a name that includes the franchisor's trademark or commercial symbol. The franchisee must adhere to quality standards set by the franchisor for the products or services to be offered, sold, or distributed, and use the franchisor's trademark or commercial symbol in their name. The franchisor also shares knowledge, expertise, trade secrets, and non-patented information with the franchisee. The franchisor communicates knowledge, experience, expertise, knowhow, trade secrets, or other non-patented information to the franchisee, provides significant assistance in the franchisee's method of operation, and exercises significant controls over the franchisee's method of operation. The franchisee must make payment or other consideration to the franchisor as a condition for obtaining or commencing operation of a franchise. The term "franchisee" refers to a person who is required to make payment or other consideration to the franchisor, or an affiliate of the franchisor, for goods at a wholesale price. This includes subfranchises or commercial relationships based on representations that the criteria will be met. The term "franchisee" means a person granted a franchise, while "franchisor" refers to the person granting the franchise. "Person" includes natural persons or legal entities. A "subfranchise" is a contract where a person pays for the right to franchise. Commercial relationships can be based on representations that criteria will be met. The term "subfranchise" refers to a contract where a person pays a franchisor for the right to sell franchises or provide goods/services to franchisees. "Person" includes natural persons or legal entities recognized in law.
